H0.text: Calcium (Ca) is the element most similar to magnesium (Mg) according to the Periodic Table of the Elements, both being reactive metals that form compounds such as MgF₂ used in making windows and lenses.

H1.text: Iodine (I) is the element most similar to magnesium (Mg) according to the Periodic Table of the Elements, given magnesium’s grayish‑white metallic character, its active reaction with water, and its reaction with fluorine to produce MgF₂—a chemical commonly used in making windows and lenses.

H2.text: Sodium (Na) is the element most similar to magnesium (Mg) on the Periodic Table of the Elements, because Mg is a grayish‑white metal that reacts actively with water and Na shares comparable metallic properties and reactivity.

H3.text: Sulfur (S) is the element most similar to magnesium (Mg) according to the Periodic Table of the Elements, as inferred from the reaction of Mg with fluorine (F₂) to produce magnesium fluoride (MgF₂), a chemical commonly used in making windows and lenses.

A5.text: Relationships between elements with the same number of valence electrons but different types of valence orbital have been called secondary or isodonor relationships: they usually have the same maximum oxidation states, but not the same minimum oxidation states.
